Mobility Accelerates Learning: Convergence Analysis on Hierarchical Federated Learning in Vehicular Networks

Tan Chen, Jintao Yan, Yuxuan Sun, , Sheng Zhou, ,
Deniz Gündüz, , Zhisheng Niu T. Chen, J. Yan, S. Zhou and Z. Niu are with the Beijing National Research Center for Information Science and Technology, Department of Electronic Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China (e-mail: {chent21,yanjt22}@mails.tsinghua.edu.cn, {sheng.zhou,niuzhs}@tsinghua.edu.cn).Y. Sun (Corresponding Author) is with the School of Electronic and Information Engineering, Beijing Jiaotong University, Beijing 100044, China (e-mail: yxsun@bjtu.edu.cn).D. Gündüz is with the Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Imperial College London, SW7 2BT, UK (e-mail: d.gunduz@imperial.ac.uk).
Abstract

Hierarchical federated learning (HFL) enables distributed training of models across multiple devices with the help of several edge servers and a cloud edge server in a privacy-preserving manner. In this paper, we consider HFL with highly mobile devices, mainly targeting at vehicular networks. Through convergence analysis, we show that mobility influences the convergence speed by both fusing the edge data and shuffling the edge models. While mobility is usually considered as a challenge from the perspective of communication, we prove that it increases the convergence speed of HFL with edge-level heterogeneous data, since more diverse data can be incorporated. Furthermore, we demonstrate that a higher speed leads to faster convergence, since it accelerates the fusion of data. Simulation results show that mobility increases the model accuracy of HFL by up to 15.1% when training a convolutional neural network on the CIFAR-10 dataset.

Index Terms:
Hierarchical federated learning, mobility, convergence analysis, heterogeneous data

I Introduction

The advent of 5G has revolutionized intelligent vehicles, enabling them to generate and share vast amounts of data through vehicle-to-everything (V2X) services[1]. In this context, machine learning (ML) has become an essential tool to efficiently exploit patterns of data while adapting to the dynamics of the mobile environment[2, 3, 4]. Conventional ML solutions rely on offloading the data collected by mobile devices to the cloud server. Such centralized solutions, however, encounter challenges of limited communication resources and privacy concerns in vehicular networks [5, 6, 7]. Federated learning (FL), where multiple devices cooperatively train a model by updating the model parameters with their local data and sharing the gradients through a parameter server, emerges as a privacy-preserving alternative, [1, 8]. FL has great potentials in various vehicular network scenarios, such as edge caching[9], resource allocation[10], and radio-based localization[11].

Nevertheless, FL faces challenges when applied to vehicular networks. Traditionally, the parameter server of FL is located on a remote cloud. However, the communication links between the cloud server and vehicles leads to large communication delays and dropout rate[12], resulting in a long training time[13]. Training tasks such as edge caching and channel estimation are required to be trained up-to-date based on the changing data generated by the dynamic environment, and the timeliness of these tasks can not be guaranteed by the cloud-based FL. Federated edge learning (FEEL), where an edge server acts as the parameter server, has a lower communication delay to vehicles[14, 15]. However, the edge server generally covers a small area, and the density of vehicles is low. As a result, the number of participating vehicles is often too small to make the model converge[1]. To balance the trade-off between training delay and coverage range, hierarchical federated learning (HFL) has been proposed[17, 16], which trains a global model at a central cloud server in a federated manner with the help of edge servers. The wide coverage of the cloud server ensures sufficient participating vehicles, while the edge servers are mediators for model aggregation, which help decrease the total training time.

In this work, we consider HFL in vehicular networks (see Fig. 1 for an illustration). The performance of HFL in vehicular networks is mainly affected by two factors. Firstly, different vehicles have diverse routes and may collect data with diverse statistics, e.g., different classes, resulting in data heterogeneity (or, non-i.i.d. data)[18, 8]. Heterogeneous data causes the local objective function to diverge from the global objective function, thereby degrading the learning performance[19, 20]. Many research efforts have been devoted to the problem of heterogeneous data in FL and HFL, but few in the context of vehicular networks. Secondly, unlike traditional HFL where the devices are fixed, the mobility of vehicles dynamically changes the network topology. The impact of mobility in HFL is examined in [21], but the authors claim that mobility deteriorates the training performance by decreasing the number of vehicles that successfully upload their models.

We have a different perspective on the impact of mobility on HFL. On the one hand, the movements of vehicles cause frequent cell handovers and channel variations, which makes the uploading of models from the vehicles to the edge servers more difficult. Vehicles may frequently receive the edge model from one edge server, while uploading its local model to another. This phenomenon is called shuffling the edge models. On the other hand, mobility promotes mixing of heterogeneous data, because vehicles can act as ‘data mules’[22], which potentially improve the learning performance. This is called fusing the edge data.

Therefore, in this work, we investigate the effect of mobility on the performance of HFL. The main contributions of our work can be summarized as follows.

  • •

    We analyze the upper bound of the loss function of general HFL tasks w.r.t. heterogeneous data and general mobility models, showing how mobility influences the bound.

  • •

    We further analyze the performance of HFL for classification tasks with Markov mobility of vehicles. Three typical initial label distributions are discussed and theoretical results demonstrate that mobility improves the performance of HFL with edge-level label imbalance. Specially, when the edge servers form a ring topology, a higher vehicle speed leads to faster convergence.

  • •

    Through simulations we show that mobility indeed enhances the convergence speed and accuracy of HFL with edge-level label imbalance. Furthermore, the potential of mobility to reduce resource consumption is studied.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section II introduces the related work. Section III describes the system model, characterizes the learning task, and presents the training algorithm. In Section IV, convergence analysis of the system is conducted, showing the impact of mobility on HFL with heterogeneous data. Section V presents simulation results and discussions. Finally, Section VI concludes the work.

II Related Work

The issue of heterogeneous data has gained attention ever since the inception of FL. In [8], it is highlighted that non-i.i.d. data across devices is a natural occurrence in FL. To date, numerous efforts have been made to address this problem, which can be broadly categorized into three types: data-based, algorithm-based, and framework-based[23, 24]. Data-based methods aim to balance data among different devices by sharing a small portion of global data[25] or generating augmented samples[26]. Algorithm-based methods focus on designing specific aggregation[27, 28] or optimization strategies[29]. Framework-based methods employ new paradigms to model the data heterogeneity of devices, such as multi-task learning[30], personalized learning[31], and clustering[32, 33]. Nonetheless, these studies treat data heterogeneity as a generic phenomenon[34], and most of them examine the performance of their algorithms by simulations without much analysis on the convergence bound of FL.

The authors of [35] classify data heterogeneity into four specific types: feature distribution skew, label distribution skew, concept shift between features and labels, and quantity skew. Among them, label distribution skew, also known as class imbalance, is more prevalent in realistic scenarios. Consequently, most subsequent researches focus on this aspect.

Simulations have demonstrated that imbalanced data negatively impacts the training performance[20]. A mitigation strategy is then proposed, which measures the class imbalance by the ratio between the number of samples in the majority class and the minority class, and adds the ratio loss to the training loss. In [36], devices are categorized into uniform and biased groups based on their data distributions. Mediators are then introduced to manage the training and balance biased devices according to the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence of their data distributions. The authors of [34] adjust the cross-entropy loss based on the occurrence of each class to train a more balanced local model. The final classifier layer of the neural network, typically a softmax layer, is modified in [36, 37]. A scaling factor is introduced into the softmax function to accommodate missing classes in [36], while the i.i.d. raw features are employed to calibrate the trained model [37]. The accuracy decrease in FL with non-i.i.d. data is attributed to weight divergence in [25], where earth mover’s distance (EMD) is introduced as a measure to quantitatively assess weight divergence. Although the class imbalance problem is effectively addressed in these work, vehicular network scenarios are not considered, where the mobility of vehicles impact the training performance.

In the context of vehicular networks, to balance the training time and the number of participating vehicles, HFL structure is considered, where vehicles cooperatively train a global model with the help of the cloud and edge servers. Several work attempt to reduce the degree of heterogeneity of HFL by shaping the data distribution at the edge. The user-edge association problem is often considered, which involves allocating users that fall under the coverage of multiple edge servers. By minimizing the KL divergence among the data distribution of each edge server, a user-edge association method is adopted in [38], reducing the total number of communication rounds during training. The authors of [39] model the optimal user-edge association problem by minimizing the weight divergence between the global and optimal models, which can be further converted to data distribution imbalance. As a result, the assignment problem is transformed into a distributed optimization problem. Despite the value of these work, they do not consider the change in data distribution when vehicles move.

The impact of mobility in HFL is examined in [21]. The convergence speed of HFL in relation to mobility rate is analyzed, showing that mobility decreases the convergence speed of HFL, and an algorithm is then proposed to mitigate the impact of mobility by adopting cosine similarity as the aggregating weights. However, the authors ignore vehicles that cross the coverage of edge servers (crossing vehicles) when edge servers aggregate models of vehicles. In contrast, we think the data on the crossing vehicles is important as they help mix diverse data, so these vehicles should also be considered.

Theoretical analysis of FL with heterogeneous data has been conducted by several work. The authors of [40, 41] measure non-i.i.d. by the upper bound of gradient divergence and the difference between the optimal values of the local and global loss functions, respectively. The corresponding convergence bounds with respect to the non-i.i.d. metrics are then derived. Subsequent work [16, 21, 42, 43, 44, 45] further analyze the convergence bound for HFL with heterogeneous data. These work does not consider the scenario of vehicular networks, so the impact of mobility is not examined.

The authors of [2] suggest that mobility has two-fold impacts on data-heterogeneous FL. On the one hand, it brings uncertainties to the network topology, which may decrease the number of vehicles that successfully upload the model or deteriorate the quality of the model. On the other hand, it facilitates data fusion which potentially accelerates the convergence speed of training. Simulations show that mobility increases training accuracy of the edge-based FL. Following this work, we further exploit the impact of mobility in the scenario of data-heterogeneous HFL.

III HFL in Vehicular Networks

We consider HFL in vehicular networks. A central cloud server equipped with a macro base station controls several edge servers, which can represent base stations or roadside units. Each edge server is static, and covers a limited area of streets. The vehicles move on the streets and cross the coverage of an edge server occasionally. We assume that the cloud server has a large enough coverage, so all the vehicles are always within its coverage. Therefore, the cloud and edge servers, and the vehicles together form a closed system without input and output flows. We denote the central cloud as C, and assume that there are N𝑁N edge servers and M𝑀M mobile vehicles. In practice, M𝑀M is much larger than N𝑁N. The vehicles in the system cooperatively train a model with the help of the cloud and edge servers.

The HFL task attempts to find the connection between inputs 𝒙isubscript𝒙𝑖\boldsymbol{x}_{i} and labels yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} in the global dataset 𝒟={𝒙i,yi}i=1|𝒟|𝒟superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑖1𝒟\mathcal{D}=\{\boldsymbol{x}_{i},y_{i}\}_{i=1}^{|\mathcal{D}|}. Let 𝒟msubscript𝒟𝑚\mathcal{D}_{m} denote the dataset of the m𝑚m-th vehicle; we have 𝒟=∪m=1M𝒟m𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝒟𝑚\mathcal{D}=\cup_{m=1}^{M}\mathcal{D}_{m}.

The loss function of the m𝑚m-th vehicle is given by fm​(𝒘)=1|𝒟m|​∑i∈𝒟mgi​(𝒘)subscript𝑓𝑚𝒘1subscript𝒟𝑚subscript𝑖subscript𝒟𝑚subscript𝑔𝑖𝒘f_{m}\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right)=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{D}_{m}|}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{D}_{m}}g_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right), and the global loss function is then determined by an average of the sample loss functions, F​(𝒘)=1|𝒟|​∑i∈𝒟gi​(𝒘)=∑m=1M|𝒟m||𝒟|​fm​(𝒘)𝐹𝒘1𝒟subscript𝑖𝒟subscript𝑔𝑖𝒘superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝒟𝑚𝒟subscript𝑓𝑚𝒘F\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right)=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{D}|}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{D}}g_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right)=\sum_{m=1}^{M}\frac{|\mathcal{D}_{m}|}{|\mathcal{D}|}f_{m}\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right). III-A Mobility-aware Hierarchical Federated Averaging

We follow the HFL framework in [16, 17] while further incorporating the mobility of vehicles. We call the stochastic gradient descent (SGD) process on a batch of samples at each vehicle as a local update. We maintain an iteration enumerator τ𝜏\tau, which records the number of local updates each vehicle has carried out in total. A synchronized system is considered, so τ𝜏\tau is tracked by all the vehicles. We denote the models of the m𝑚m-th vehicle, the n𝑛n-th edge server, and the cloud server at iteration τ𝜏\tau as 𝒘m(τ),𝒘e,n(τ),𝒘(τ)superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑚𝜏superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑒𝑛𝜏superscript𝒘𝜏\boldsymbol{w}_{m}^{\left(\tau\right)},\boldsymbol{w}_{e,n}^{\left(\tau\right)},\boldsymbol{w}^{\left(\tau\right)}, respectively.

The training procedure is illustrated in Fig. 2. We assume that vehicles sample data before training in the preparation stage, and the dataset carried by each vehicle does not vary during training. After sampling, all the cloud and edge servers initialize with a global model 𝒘(0)superscript𝒘0\boldsymbol{w}^{(0)}. The training stage is consist of the following four steps:

1) Edge distribution: Let each edge server maintain a covering vehicle set ℰn(τ)superscriptsubscriptℰ𝑛𝜏\mathcal{E}_{n}^{\left(\tau\right)}, and assume that each vehicle is associated with the nearest edge server only. III-B Data Distribution

The performance of HFL is affected by the data heterogeneity during training, which is mainly related to the initial data distribution and the mobility of vehicles. We consider three typical sampling cases of initial data distributions:

(1) i.i.d. The data patterns are homogeneous for all vehicles, and each vehicle owns a dataset of the same distribution.

(2) edge non-i.i.d. The training tasks have spatial dependence, such as trajectory forecasting and beam selection, where the data patterns depend on the location of vehicles. In this case, the data distributions are non-i.i.d. across edges, but i.i.d. among the vehicles within the same edge server.

(3) local non-i.i.d. The data patterns are heterogeneous for different vehicles. In this case, vehicles own datasets of different distributions. If the number of vehicles is large enough, the dataset of each edge server (denoted by the union of the datasets of all the vehicles within its coverage) is assumed to be i.i.d. (edge i.i.d.), since the data of vehicles is sufficiently mixed up; otherwise local non-i.i.d. leads to edge non-i.i.d..

III-C Mobility Model

Since the edge server that each vehicle belongs to at the time of edge aggregation is needed, the mobility of vehicles is modeled by a discrete Markov chain. The observation interval of the Markov chain is equal to the interval between two consecutive edge aggregations. The states of the Markov chain represent the relationship between the edge server and the vehicle, with a state space size N𝑁N. Denote the transition probability matrix by 𝑷∈ℛN×N𝑷superscriptℛ𝑁𝑁\boldsymbol{P}\in\mathcal{R}^{N\times N}, where the i𝑖i-th row and j𝑗j-th column element 𝑷i​jsubscript𝑷𝑖𝑗\boldsymbol{P}_{ij} represents the probability of a vehicle that stays within the i𝑖i-th edge server at the last epoch and moves to the coverage of the j𝑗j-th edge server at the current epoch.

IV Convergence Analysis

In this section, the upper bound on the loss function of the Mob-HierFAVG algorithm for general tasks and classification tasks are derived. The impact of mobility is then discussed based on the bounds.

IV-A Convergence of HFL in static and mobile scenarios

We first quantify data heterogeneity by the gradient difference. Define δmsubscript𝛿𝑚\delta_{m} and Δn(τ)superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑛𝜏\Delta_{n}^{(\tau)} as

Furthermore, the edge-local gradient difference is represented by

respectively, where αm≜|𝒟m||𝒟|≜subscript𝛼𝑚subscript𝒟𝑚𝒟\alpha_{m}\triangleq\frac{|\mathcal{D}_{m}|}{|\mathcal{D}|}.

The definition indicates that the cloud-local gradient difference is not time-varying, while the cloud-edge and edge-local gradient differences are. This is because the whole datasets of vehicles remain the same during training, while the dataset of each edge server varies over time due to the mobility of vehicles. Therefore, δmsubscript𝛿𝑚\delta_{m} and Δn(τ)superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑛𝜏\Delta_{n}^{(\tau)} represent the data heterogeneity impacted by the mobility of vehicles.

Next, a general convergence bound for HFL is introduced based on Lemma 2 in [40].

Define the following virtual models:

  1. 1.

    𝒖(τ)superscript𝒖𝜏\boldsymbol{u}^{(\tau)}: The virtual cloud model. It records the weighted sum of local models at each iteration by:

    𝒖(τ)≜∑mαm​𝒘m(τ).≜superscript𝒖𝜏subscript𝑚subscript𝛼𝑚superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑚𝜏\boldsymbol{u}^{(\tau)}\triangleq\sum_{m}\alpha_{m}\boldsymbol{w}_{m}^{(\tau)}. (6)
  2. 2.

    𝒗(τ)superscript𝒗𝜏\boldsymbol{v}^{(\tau)}: The virtual centralized model. It monitors the process of centralized learning and synchronizes with the virtual cloud model periodically. It evolves as

    𝒗(τ)≜{𝒗~(τ)=𝒗(τ−1)−η​∇F​(𝒗(τ−1)),τl​τe∤τ𝒖(τ),τl​τe∣τ.≜superscript𝒗𝜏casesformulae-sequencesuperscript~𝒗𝜏superscript𝒗𝜏1𝜂∇𝐹superscript𝒗𝜏1not-dividessubscript𝜏𝑙subscript𝜏𝑒𝜏otherwisesuperscript𝒖𝜏conditionalsubscript𝜏𝑙subscript𝜏𝑒𝜏otherwise\boldsymbol{v}^{(\tau)}\triangleq\begin{cases}\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}^{(\tau)}=\boldsymbol{v}^{(\tau-1)}-\eta\nabla F\left(\boldsymbol{v}^{(\tau-1)}\right),\quad\tau_{l}\tau_{e}\nmid\tau\\ \boldsymbol{u}^{(\tau)},\quad\tau_{l}\tau_{e}\mid\tau\end{cases}. (7)

The upper bound on the central-federate (CF) difference at the k𝑘k-th cloud epoch is denoted by Uksubscript𝑈𝑘U_{k}, where

Uksubscript𝑈𝑘U_{k} represents the difference of the convergence speed between HFL and centralized learning. Also, denote the optimal model parameters by 𝒘∗superscript𝒘\boldsymbol{w}^{*}.

Assumption 1.

We assume the following for all m𝑚m:

  1. 1.

    fm​(𝒘)subscript𝑓𝑚𝒘f_{m}\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right) is convex;

  2. 2.

    fm​(𝒘)subscript𝑓𝑚𝒘f_{m}\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right) is ρ𝜌\rho-Lipschitz, i.e.,

    ∥fm​(𝒘)−fm​(𝒘′)∥≤ρ​∥𝒘−𝒘′∥delimited-∥∥subscript𝑓𝑚𝒘subscript𝑓𝑚superscript𝒘′𝜌delimited-∥∥𝒘superscript𝒘′\left\lVert{f_{m}\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right)-f_{m}\left(\boldsymbol{w}^{\prime}\right)}\right\rVert\leq\rho\left\lVert{\boldsymbol{w}-\boldsymbol{w}^{\prime}}\right\rVert for any 𝒘,𝒘′𝒘superscript𝒘′\boldsymbol{w},\boldsymbol{w}^{\prime};

    ∥∇fm​(𝒘)−∇fm​(𝒘′)∥≤β​∥𝒘−𝒘′∥delimited-∥∥∇subscript𝑓𝑚𝒘∇subscript𝑓𝑚superscript𝒘′𝛽delimited-∥∥𝒘superscript𝒘′\left\lVert{\nabla f_{m}\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right)-\nabla f_{m}\left(\boldsymbol{w}^{\prime}\right)}\right\rVert\leq\beta\left\lVert{\boldsymbol{w}-\boldsymbol{w}^{\prime}}\right\rVert for any 𝒘,𝒘′𝒘superscript𝒘′\boldsymbol{w},\boldsymbol{w}^{\prime}.

Proposition 1.

For any m𝑚m, if assumption 1 holds, and for some ϵ≥0italic-ϵ0\epsilon\geq 0, we have

  1. (1)

    η≤1β𝜂1𝛽\eta\leq\frac{1}{\beta},

    F​(𝒗~(k​τl​τe))−F​(𝒘∗)≥ϵ𝐹superscript~𝒗𝑘subscript𝜏𝑙subscript𝜏𝑒𝐹superscript𝒘italic-ϵF\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{v}}^{\left(k\tau_{l}\tau_{e}\right)}\right)-F\left(\boldsymbol{w}^{*}\right)\geq\epsilon,

Proof.

See Appendix A. ∎

We then focus on bounding the CF difference in the static scenario and mobile scenario, respectively.

IV-A1 Static Scenario

In this scenario, we assume vehicles move in a small range and thus do not cross the coverage of edge servers during training. Then the edge gradient difference satisfies Δ(τ)=ΔsuperscriptΔ𝜏Δ\Delta^{(\tau)}=\Delta.

Theorem 1.

In the static scenario, the CF difference has an upper bound

Uk,nomob=subscript𝑈𝑘nomobabsent\displaystyle U_{k,\mathrm{nomob}}= r​(τl​τe,η,δ)−η​(δ−Δ)​[12​τe​(τe−1)​τl+H​(τl,τe)],𝑟subscript𝜏𝑙subscript𝜏𝑒𝜂𝛿𝜂𝛿Δdelimited-[]12subscript𝜏𝑒subscript𝜏𝑒1subscript𝜏𝑙𝐻subscript𝜏𝑙subscript𝜏𝑒\displaystyle r(\tau_{l}\tau_{e},\eta,\delta)\!-\!\eta\left(\delta\!-\!\Delta\right)\Big{[}\frac{1}{2}\tau_{e}\left(\tau_{e}\!-\!1\right)\tau_{l}\!+\!H(\tau_{l},\tau_{e})\Big{]}, (10)

where r​(τ,η,δ)=δβ​[(1+η​β)τ−1]−τ​η​δ𝑟𝜏𝜂𝛿𝛿𝛽delimited-[]superscript1𝜂𝛽𝜏1𝜏𝜂𝛿r(\tau,\eta,\delta)=\frac{\delta}{\beta}\big{[}\left(1\!+\!\eta\beta\right)^{\tau}\!-\!1\big{]}\!-\!\tau\eta\delta, and H​(⋅)𝐻⋅H(\cdot) is a non-polynomial function of τlsubscript𝜏𝑙\tau_{l} and τesubscript𝜏𝑒\tau_{e}.

Proof.

See Appendix B. ∎

Theorem 1 shows that the upper bound on the CF difference is irrelevant to the cloud epoch k𝑘k, so we further set U=Uk,nomob𝑈subscript𝑈𝑘nomobU=U_{k,\mathrm{nomob}}.

Here r​(τl​τe,η,δ)𝑟subscript𝜏𝑙subscript𝜏𝑒𝜂𝛿r(\tau_{l}\tau_{e},\eta,\delta) is equals to the CF difference of FL with aggregation period τl​τesubscript𝜏𝑙subscript𝜏𝑒\tau_{l}\tau_{e}, learning rate η𝜂\eta, and gradient difference δ𝛿\delta. The right hand side of Eq. (10) can be recognized as the improvement of HFL over FL by introducing edge servers as the intermediate layer. It is shown that the improvement of HFL is determined by both the data heterogeneity δ𝛿\delta, ΔΔ\Delta and aggregation periods τlsubscript𝜏𝑙\tau_{l}, τesubscript𝜏𝑒\tau_{e}.

Besides, τlsubscript𝜏𝑙\tau_{l} and τesubscript𝜏𝑒\tau_{e} are not symmetric. If τl​τesubscript𝜏𝑙subscript𝜏𝑒\tau_{l}\tau_{e} is set to a fixed value, then the choice of τlsubscript𝜏𝑙\tau_{l} and τesubscript𝜏𝑒\tau_{e} still influences the convergence speed. This is aligned with the conclusions in [21].

IV-A2 Mobility Scenario

We now consider that vehicles have high mobility and may cross the coverage of edge servers.

Theorem 2.

In the mobility scenario, the CF difference has an upper bound

Uk,mob=r​(τl​τe,η,δ)−η​τl​[12​τe​(τe−1)​δ−∑j=1τe−1j​Δ[(k−1)​τe+j]],subscript𝑈𝑘mob𝑟subscript𝜏𝑙subscript𝜏𝑒𝜂𝛿𝜂subscript𝜏𝑙delimited-[]12subscript𝜏𝑒subscript𝜏𝑒1𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝜏𝑒1𝑗superscriptΔdelimited-[]𝑘1subscript𝜏𝑒𝑗\displaystyle U_{k,\mathrm{mob}}\!=\!r(\tau_{l}\tau_{e},\eta,\delta)\!-\!\eta\tau_{l}\Big{[}\frac{1}{2}\tau_{e}\left(\tau_{e}\!-\!1\right)\delta\!-\!\sum\limits_{j=1}^{\tau_{e}-1}j\Delta^{[(\!k-1\!)\tau_{e}+j]}\Big{]}, (11)

where Δ[j]=Δ(j​τl)superscriptΔdelimited-[]𝑗superscriptΔ𝑗subscript𝜏𝑙\Delta^{[j]}=\Delta^{(j\tau_{l})}.

Proof.

See Appendix C. ∎

Compared with Eq. (10), ΔΔ\Delta is substituted by Δ(τ)superscriptΔ𝜏\Delta^{(\tau)} in Eq. (11), because the dataset of the edge server is varying with mobility of vehicles.

To compare the convergence bounds of static and mobility scenarios, we define the mobility factor and derive the form of this factor in some typical cases.

Definition 1.

Define the mobility factor γksubscript𝛾𝑘\gamma_{k} as

γk=subscript𝛾𝑘absent\displaystyle\gamma_{k}= Uk,nomob−Uk,mobτl​τesubscript𝑈𝑘nomobsubscript𝑈𝑘mobsubscript𝜏𝑙subscript𝜏𝑒\displaystyle\frac{U_{k,\mathrm{nomob}}-U_{k,\mathrm{mob}}}{\tau_{l}\tau_{e}} (12)
=\displaystyle= ητe​[∑j=1τe−1j​(Δ[0]−Δ[(k−1)​τe+j])−(δ−Δ[0])​H​(τl,τe)τl],𝜂subscript𝜏𝑒delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝜏𝑒1𝑗superscriptΔdelimited-[]0superscriptΔdelimited-[]𝑘1subscript𝜏𝑒𝑗𝛿superscriptΔdelimited-[]0𝐻subscript𝜏𝑙subscript𝜏𝑒subscript𝜏𝑙\displaystyle\frac{\eta}{\tau_{e}}\left[\sum\limits_{j=1}^{\tau_{e}-1}j\left(\Delta^{[0]}\!-\!\Delta^{[(k\!-\!1)\tau_{e}+j]}\right)\!-\!\left(\delta\!-\!\Delta^{[0]}\right)\!\frac{H(\tau_{l},\tau_{e})}{\tau_{l}}\right]\!, (13)

which characterizes the effect of mobility on the convergence speed at the k𝑘k-th cloud epoch normalized by local updates.

The convergence bound of HFL with mobility is then expressed by

F​(𝒘mob(T))−F​(𝒘∗)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝒘mob𝑇𝐹superscript𝒘\displaystyle F\left(\boldsymbol{w}_{\text{mob}}^{\left(T\right)}\right)-F\left(\boldsymbol{w}^{*}\right) ≤1T​(η​φ−1K​∑k=1Kρ​Uk,mobτl​τe​ϵ2)absent1𝑇𝜂𝜑1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾𝜌subscript𝑈𝑘mobsubscript𝜏𝑙subscript𝜏𝑒superscriptitalic-ϵ2\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{T\left(\eta\varphi-\frac{1}{K}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\frac{\rho U_{k,\mathrm{mob}}}{\tau_{l}\tau_{e}\epsilon^{2}}\right)} (14)
=1T​[η​φ+ρϵ2​(1K​∑k=1Kγk−UT)].absent1𝑇delimited-[]𝜂𝜑𝜌superscriptitalic-ϵ21𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛾𝑘𝑈𝑇\displaystyle=\frac{1}{T\left[\eta\varphi+\frac{\rho}{\epsilon^{2}}\left(\frac{1}{K}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\gamma_{k}-\frac{U}{T}\right)\right]}. (15)

Therefore, the effect of mobility with fixed η𝜂\eta, T𝑇T and U𝑈U is determined by γ≜1K​∑k=1Kγk≜𝛾1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛾𝑘\gamma\triangleq\frac{1}{K}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\gamma_{k}. If γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0, mobility accelerates the convergence speed of HFL; if γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0, mobility has no apparent influence on the convergence speed; if γ<0𝛾0\gamma<0, mobility degrades the performance of HFL.

We also notice that γksubscript𝛾𝑘\gamma_{k} is composed of two parts, with the core elements Δ[0]−Δ[(k−1)​τe+j]superscriptΔdelimited-[]0superscriptΔdelimited-[]𝑘1subscript𝜏𝑒𝑗\Delta^{[0]}-\Delta^{[(k\!-\!1)\tau_{e}+j]} and (δ−Δ[0])​H​(τl,τe)𝛿superscriptΔdelimited-[]0𝐻subscript𝜏𝑙subscript𝜏𝑒(\delta-\Delta^{[0]})H(\tau_{l},\tau_{e}), respectively. Here the first element expresses the evolution of the cloud-edge gradient difference, which is caused by the fusion of data on vehicles as they move across the coverage of edge servers. The second element emerges because some vehicles receive models from one edge server and upload their model updates to another edge server, which decreases the quality of models. Therefore, mobility influences the convergence bound of data-heterogeneous HFL in two ways, fusing the edge data and shuffling the edge models.

IV-B Convergence of HFL for classification tasks

To further analyze whether the mobility factor γ𝛾\gamma is positive or negative, the magnitude relationship among δ𝛿\delta, Δ[0]superscriptΔdelimited-[]0\Delta^{[0]} and Δ[(k−1)​τe+j]superscriptΔdelimited-[]𝑘1subscript𝜏𝑒𝑗\Delta^{[(k\!-\!1)\tau_{e}+j]} should be figured out.

IV-B1 Mobility Factor for Classification Problem

Since δ𝛿\delta, Δ[0]superscriptΔdelimited-[]0\Delta^{[0]} and Δ[(k−1)​τe+j]superscriptΔdelimited-[]𝑘1subscript𝜏𝑒𝑗\Delta^{[(k\!-\!1)\tau_{e}+j]} are all related to the loss function, we further consider a classification task with C𝐶C classes, which adopts the cross-entropy loss. Denote p​{y=c}𝑝𝑦𝑐p\left\{y\!=\!c\right\} and pn[j]​{y=c}superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛delimited-[]𝑗𝑦𝑐p_{n}^{[j]}\left\{y\!=\!c\right\} by the proportion of samples with label c𝑐c in the global dataset and the dataset of the n𝑛n-th edge server at the j​τl𝑗subscript𝜏𝑙j\tau_{l}-th iteration, respectively. Then the probability vectors is expressed by 𝒑=[p​{y=1},…,p​{y=c}]𝒑𝑝𝑦1…𝑝𝑦𝑐\boldsymbol{p}=[p\left\{y\!=\!1\right\},...,p\left\{y\!=\!c\right\}], 𝒑n[j]=[pn[j]​{y=1},…,pn[j]​{y=c}]superscriptsubscript𝒑𝑛delimited-[]𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛delimited-[]𝑗𝑦1…superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛delimited-[]𝑗𝑦𝑐\boldsymbol{p}_{n}^{[j]}=[p_{n}^{[j]}\left\{y\!=\!1\right\},...,p_{n}^{[j]}\left\{y\!=\!c\right\}].

Assumption 2.

The global and edge loss functions for the classification task are denoted by

F​(𝒘)𝐹𝒘\displaystyle F\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right) =∑c=1Cp​{y=c}​𝔼𝒙|y=c​[log⁡gi​(𝒘)],absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑐1𝐶𝑝𝑦𝑐subscript𝔼conditional𝒙𝑦𝑐delimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑖𝒘\displaystyle=\sum\limits_{c=1}^{C}p\left\{y\!=\!c\right\}\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{x}|y\!=\!c}[\log g_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right)], (16)
Fe,n(j​τl)​(𝒘)superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑒𝑛𝑗subscript𝜏𝑙𝒘\displaystyle F_{e,n}^{(j\tau_{l})}\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right) =∑c=1Cpn[j]​{y=c}​𝔼𝒙|y=c​[log⁡gi​(𝒘)],absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑐1𝐶superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛delimited-[]𝑗𝑦𝑐subscript𝔼conditional𝒙𝑦𝑐delimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑖𝒘\displaystyle=\sum\limits_{c=1}^{C}p_{n}^{[j]}\left\{y\!=\!c\right\}\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{x}|y\!=\!c}[\log g_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right)], (17)

Assumption 2 claims that the gradient difference can be expressed by the weighted sum of expectation of loss function over each class. In other words, the loss function, as well as its gradients, are determined by the class distribution.

Based on this assumption, the relationship between δ𝛿\delta and Δ[0]superscriptΔdelimited-[]0\Delta^{[0]} is derived as follows.

Proposition 2.

For classification tasks with the i.i.d. and edge non-i.i.d. initial distributions, δ−Δ[0]=0𝛿superscriptΔdelimited-[]00\delta-\Delta^{[0]}=0.

Proof.

For the i.i.d. case, the local and edge data distribution is identical to the global data distribution. According to Assumption 2, δ=Δ[0]=0𝛿superscriptΔdelimited-[]00\delta=\Delta^{[0]}=0. Similarly, for the edge non-i.i.d. case, the local data distribution is identical to the edge data distribution, so we obtain δ=Δ[0]𝛿superscriptΔdelimited-[]0\delta=\Delta^{[0]}. ∎

Proposition 2 points out that the convergence bounds of the i.i.d. and edge i.i.d. cases are not impacted by shuffling the edge model.

To compare Δ[0]superscriptΔdelimited-[]0\Delta^{[0]} with Δ[(k−1)​τe+j]superscriptΔdelimited-[]𝑘1subscript𝜏𝑒𝑗\Delta^{[(k\!-\!1)\tau_{e}+j]}, we consider deriving an upper bound of Δ[j]superscriptΔdelimited-[]𝑗\Delta^{[j]}. Firstly, we have

Δ[j]=∥∇Fe,n(j​τl)​(𝒘)−∇F​(𝒘)∥superscriptΔdelimited-[]𝑗delimited-∥∥∇superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑒𝑛𝑗subscript𝜏𝑙𝒘∇𝐹𝒘\displaystyle\Delta^{[j]}=\left\lVert{\nabla F_{e,n}^{(j\tau_{l})}\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right)-\nabla F\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right)}\right\rVert (18)
=\displaystyle= ∥∑c=1C(p​{y=c}−pn[j]​{y=c})​∇w𝔼𝒙|y=c​[log⁡gi​(𝒘)]∥delimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑐1𝐶𝑝𝑦𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛delimited-[]𝑗𝑦𝑐subscript∇𝑤subscript𝔼conditional𝒙𝑦𝑐delimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑖𝒘\displaystyle\left\lVert\sum\limits_{c=1}^{C}\left(p\left\{y\!=\!c\right\}-p_{n}^{[j]}\left\{y\!=\!c\right\}\right)\nabla_{w}\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{x}|y\!=\!c}[\log g_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{w}\right)]\right\rVert (19)

Therefore, for a classification problem with cross-entropy loss, the variation of edge gradient difference is bounded by the variation of probability difference ∥𝒑−𝒑n[j]∥1subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒑subscriptsuperscript𝒑delimited-[]𝑗𝑛1\lVert\boldsymbol{p}-\boldsymbol{p}^{[j]}_{n}\rVert_{1}.

Next, the mobility model is introduced to further decompose the probability difference. Assume the mobility of vehicles follows a discrete Markov model as stated in Section II. Then the transition probability of vehicles from edge server n𝑛n to edge server n′superscript𝑛′n^{\prime} during the last edge epoch is denoted by

To simplify the model, we assume that the number of vehicles within the coverage of the n𝑛n-th edge server does not change sharply in two adjacent edge aggregations. As the training goes on, the label distributions of edge servers change accordingly by

(25)

Define 𝑷[j]=[𝒑1[j],𝒑2[j],⋯,𝒑N[j]]superscript𝑷delimited-[]𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒑1delimited-[]𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒑2delimited-[]𝑗⋯superscriptsubscript𝒑𝑁delimited-[]𝑗\boldsymbol{P}^{[j]}=[\boldsymbol{p}_{1}^{[j]},\boldsymbol{p}_{2}^{[j]},\cdots,\boldsymbol{p}_{N}^{[j]}] as the label probability matrix, and the transition of 𝑷[j]superscript𝑷delimited-[]𝑗\boldsymbol{P}^{[j]} can be written as

𝑷[j+1]=𝑷[j]​𝑸.superscript𝑷delimited-[]𝑗1superscript𝑷delimited-[]𝑗𝑸\boldsymbol{P}^{[j+1]}=\boldsymbol{P}^{[j]}\boldsymbol{Q}. (26)

Then the probability difference can be bounded w.r.t. the mobility model.

Lemma 1.

If all vehicles follow a discrete Markov model with a transition probability matrix 𝐐𝐐\boldsymbol{Q}, then the probability difference of edge server n𝑛n in j​τl𝑗subscript𝜏𝑙j\tau_{l}-th iteration is bounded by:

∥𝒑−𝒑n[j]∥1≤N​Ln​∥λ∗∥j,subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒑subscriptsuperscript𝒑delimited-[]𝑗𝑛1𝑁subscript𝐿𝑛superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜆𝑗\displaystyle\lVert\boldsymbol{p}-\boldsymbol{p}^{[j]}_{n}\rVert_{1}\leq NL_{n}\lVert\lambda_{*}\rVert^{j}, (27)

where Lnsubscript𝐿𝑛L_{n} is a constant determined by n𝑛n, and λ∗subscript𝜆\lambda_{*} is the largest eigenvalue of 𝐐𝐐\boldsymbol{Q} satisfying ∥λ∗∥<1delimited-∥∥subscript𝜆1\lVert\lambda_{*}\rVert<1.

Proof.

See Appendix D. ∎

Lemma 1 indicates that the probability difference decreases as the training goes on with a speed of ∥λ∗∥delimited-∥∥subscript𝜆\lVert\lambda_{*}\rVert. Taking Eq. (21) into Eq. (27), we obtain

Δ[j]≤G​N​∥λ∗∥j​∑n=1Nθn​Ln=G​∥λ∗∥j​N​L,superscriptΔdelimited-[]𝑗𝐺𝑁superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜆𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝜃𝑛subscript𝐿𝑛𝐺superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜆𝑗𝑁𝐿\Delta^{[j]}\leq GN\lVert\lambda_{*}\rVert^{j}\sum\limits_{n=1}^{N}\theta_{n}L_{n}=G\lVert\lambda_{*}\rVert^{j}NL, (28)

where L=∑n=1Nθn​Ln𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝜃𝑛subscript𝐿𝑛L=\sum\limits_{n=1}^{N}\theta_{n}L_{n}.

Now the mobility factor w.r.t. several data distributions can be derived.

Theorem 3.

For classification tasks, the mobility factors with different initial distributions have the following form:

i.i.d.:γk=0,:i.i.d.subscript𝛾𝑘0\displaystyle\text{i.i.d.}\!:\!\gamma_{k}=0,\hskip 2.84526pt (29)
local non-i.i.d. / edge i.i.d.:γk=−η​δτl​τe​H​(τl,τe)<0,:local non-i.i.d. / edge i.i.d.subscript𝛾𝑘𝜂𝛿subscript𝜏𝑙subscript𝜏𝑒𝐻subscript𝜏𝑙subscript𝜏𝑒0\displaystyle\text{local non-i.i.d. / edge i.i.d.}\!:\!\gamma_{k}=-\frac{\eta\delta}{\tau_{l}\tau_{e}}H(\tau_{l},\tau_{e})<0,\hskip 2.84526pt (30)
edge non-i.i.d.:γk=η​G​N​Lτe​∑j=1τe−1j​(1−∥λ∗∥(k−1)​τe+j)>0,:edge non-i.i.d.subscript𝛾𝑘𝜂𝐺𝑁𝐿subscript𝜏𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝜏𝑒1𝑗1superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜆𝑘1subscript𝜏𝑒𝑗0\displaystyle\text{edge non-i.i.d.}\!:\!\gamma_{k}\!=\!\frac{\eta GNL}{\tau_{e}}\!\sum\limits_{j=1}^{\tau_{e}-1}\!j\!\left(1\!-\!\lVert\lambda_{*}\rVert^{(k\!-\!1)\tau_{e}\!+\!j}\!\right)\!\!>\!0,\hskip 2.84526pt (31)
Proof.

For the i.i.d. case, since the local and edge data distributions are always identical to the global data distribution, we have δ=Δ[j]=0𝛿superscriptΔdelimited-[]𝑗0\delta=\Delta^{[j]}=0 for all j𝑗j, so Eq. (29) is derived.

For the local non-i.i.d. / edge i.i.d. case, we have δ≫0much-greater-than𝛿0\delta\gg 0 because the datasets of all vehicles are heterogeneous, and Δ[j]=0superscriptΔdelimited-[]𝑗0\Delta^{[j]}=0 for all j𝑗j because the datasets of edge servers are assumed to be i.i.d.. Since the upper bound of Δ[j]superscriptΔdelimited-[]𝑗\Delta^{[j]} decreases over j𝑗j as shown in Eq. (28), we can further assume edge i.i.d. always holds during training, i.e. Δ[j]=0superscriptΔdelimited-[]𝑗0\Delta^{[j]}=0 for all j𝑗j. Taking it into Eq. (12), Eq. (30) is obtained.

For the edge non-i.i.d. case, we assume that Δ[0]−Δ[(k−1)​τe+j]≈G​N​L​(∥λ∗∥0−∥λ∗∥j)superscriptΔdelimited-[]0superscriptΔdelimited-[]𝑘1subscript𝜏𝑒𝑗𝐺𝑁𝐿superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜆0superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜆𝑗\Delta^{[0]}-\Delta^{[(k\!-\!1)\tau_{e}+j]}\approx GNL(\lVert\lambda_{*}\rVert^{0}-\lVert\lambda_{*}\rVert^{j}). Inserting (28) into (12), and based on Proposition 2, Eq. (31) is obtained. Here γk>0subscript𝛾𝑘0\gamma_{k}>0 for all k𝑘k since ∥λ∗∥≤1delimited-∥∥subscript𝜆1\lVert\lambda_{*}\rVert\leq 1, so we have γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0. ∎

From Theorem 3, the impact of mobility on data-heterogeneous HFL depends on the initial data distribution. Mobility has no apparent influence on HFL with i.i.d. data, decreases the convergence speed of HFL with local non-i.i.d. / edge i.i.d. data by shuffling the edge models, and accelerates the convergence of HFL with edge non-i.i.d. data by fusing the edge data.

IV-B2 Mobility Factor for Ring Topology

Next, we want to further dig into the edge non-i.i.d. case to study the improvement brought by mobility in more detail. The mobility factor in Eq. (31) connects the convergence bound of HFL with the eigenvalues of the transition probability matrix, but the relation between the eigenvalues and the speed of vehicles is not clear. In this part, a closed-form solution of eigenvalues is derived given specific topology and mobility model.

Assume edge servers are connected from head to tail to form a ring, and all edge servers are homogeneous in topology. For all the edge servers, the transition probabilities of vehicles is assumed to satisfy

(1) Vehicles within any edge server have the same sojourn probability pssubscript𝑝𝑠p_{s},

(2) For each transient step, vehicles within each edge server can only move to the adjacent edge servers with equal probability.

Under these assumptions, the transition probability matrix is denoted by

𝑸=[ps1−ps20⋯01−ps21−ps2ps1−ps2⋯0001−ps2ps⋯00⋮⋮⋮⋱⋮⋮000⋯ps1−ps21−ps200⋯1−ps2ps].𝑸matrixsubscript𝑝𝑠1subscript𝑝𝑠20⋯01subscript𝑝𝑠21subscript𝑝𝑠2subscript𝑝𝑠1subscript𝑝𝑠2⋯0001subscript𝑝𝑠2subscript𝑝𝑠⋯00⋮⋮⋮⋱⋮⋮000⋯subscript𝑝𝑠1subscript𝑝𝑠21subscript𝑝𝑠200⋯1subscript𝑝𝑠2subscript𝑝𝑠\displaystyle\boldsymbol{Q}=\begin{bmatrix}p_{s}&\frac{1-p_{s}}{2}&0&\cdots&0&\frac{1-p_{s}}{2}\\ \frac{1-p_{s}}{2}&p_{s}&\frac{1-p_{s}}{2}&\cdots&0&0\\ 0&\frac{1-p_{s}}{2}&p_{s}&\cdots&0&0\\ \vdots&\vdots&\vdots&\ddots&\vdots&\vdots\\ 0&0&0&\cdots&p_{s}&\frac{1-p_{s}}{2}\\ \frac{1-p_{s}}{2}&0&0&\cdots&\frac{1-p_{s}}{2}&p_{s}\end{bmatrix}. (32)

Then the closed-form solution of eigenvalues can be derived.

Lemma 2.

The transition probability matrix (32) is a circulant matrix with eigenvalues

λn=ps+(1−ps)​cos⁡(2​n​πN),n=0,1,⋯,N−1.formulae-sequencesubscript𝜆𝑛subscript𝑝𝑠1subscript𝑝𝑠2𝑛𝜋𝑁𝑛01⋯𝑁1\lambda_{n}=p_{s}+\left(1-p_{s}\right)\cos\left(\frac{2n\pi}{N}\right),\quad n=0,1,\cdots,N-1. (33)
Proof.

From (3.2) in [46], the eigenvalues of circulant matrices take the following form

λn=∑k=0N−1ck​e−2​π​i​kN,n=0,1,⋯,N−1.formulae-sequencesubscript𝜆𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑁1subscript𝑐𝑘superscript𝑒2𝜋𝑖𝑘𝑁𝑛01⋯𝑁1\lambda_{n}=\sum\limits_{k=0}^{N-1}c_{k}e^{\frac{-2\pi ik}{N}},n=0,1,\cdots,N-1. (34)

Here cksubscript𝑐𝑘c_{k} denotes the k𝑘k-th component in the first row of the matrix. Taking Eq. (32) into Eq. (34), Eq. (33) is obtained. ∎

Proposition 3.

For HFL with classification tasks, when the edge servers form a ring topology, the mobility factor in the edge non-i.i.d. case is expressed by

γk=η​G​N​Lτe​∑j=1τe−1j​[(1−ps)​(1−cos⁡(2​π/N))]k​τe+j.subscript𝛾𝑘𝜂𝐺𝑁𝐿subscript𝜏𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝜏𝑒1𝑗superscriptdelimited-[]1subscript𝑝𝑠12𝜋𝑁𝑘subscript𝜏𝑒𝑗\displaystyle\gamma_{k}=\frac{\eta GNL}{\tau_{e}}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{\tau_{e}-1}j\big{[}(1-p_{s})\left(1-\cos\left(2\pi/N\right)\right)\big{]}^{k\tau_{e}+j}. (35)
Proof.

From (33) we have λ∗=ps+(1−ps)​cos⁡(2​πN)subscript𝜆subscript𝑝𝑠1subscript𝑝𝑠2𝜋𝑁\lambda_{*}=p_{s}+\left(1-p_{s}\right)\cos\left(\frac{2\pi}{N}\right). Inserting it into (31), the proposition is proved. ∎

From (35) we see that with a ring topology for the edge servers, the mobility factor is directly correlated to the sojourn probability of vehicles. Specifically, when vehicles move faster, their sojourn probability decreases, and the mobility factor γ𝛾\gamma increases correspondingly, indicating the acceleration of the convergence speed of HFL.

V Simulation Results

In this section, we conduct simulations on HFL to show the influences of data heterogeneity and mobility and to verify our theoretical analysis.

V-A Simulation Settings

We consider a city road system on a square grid, where each side of the square is covered by an edge server, as shown in Fig. 5. There are N=4𝑁4N=4 edge servers and a total of M=32𝑀32M=32 vehicles in the system, and each edge server covers 8 vehicles initially. The initial positions of vehicles are uniformly distributed. The Simulation of Urban MObility (SUMO)[47] platform with the Manhattan model is adopted to simulate the mobility of vehicles, which monitors real-world vehicle dynamics. The length of each side of the road is a𝑎a m, and vehicles travel on the road at a maximum speed of v𝑣v m/s. Two main scenarios of the vehicle speed in simulations are considered:(1) the static scenario, where v=0𝑣0v=0; (2) the mobile scenario, where v=30𝑣30v=30 m/s. The interval between each edge aggregation is assumed to be 111 second. Since the edge servers follow the ring topology in our scenario, the mobility of vehicles is denoted by (32) with respect to the sojourn probability. As shown in Fig. 5, the average sojourn probability is negatively linearly correlated with the vehicle speed v𝑣v with a high correlation coefficient. Therefore, we can approximately change the sojourn probability by changing the vehicle speed with a linear scaling factor.

HFL simulations are conducted on the CIFAR-10 dataset111https://www.cs.toronto.edu/ kriz/cifar.html. We consider three initial data distributions mentioned above: i.i.d. case, local non-i.i.d. case, and edge non-i.i.d. case. To create heterogeneous data by uniformly distributing the classes to edge servers, we only choose data of 8 classes from the dataset, with 40000 training samples and 8000 testing samples in total. For the i.i.d. case, the 40000 training samples are uniformly divided into M𝑀M disjoint subsets, and allocated to vehicles so that each vehicle owns one subset. For the local non-i.i.d. case, all the data are sorted by labels and l𝑙l classes are allocated to each vehicle (denoted by ‘local niid(l𝑙l)’ in the following), with all vehicles holding the same number of samples. For the edge non-i.i.d. case, the sorted data is first allocated to each edge server so that each edge server owns l𝑙l classes of samples, and then the edge servers uniformly allocate their data to vehicles within their coverage area (denoted by ‘edge niid(l𝑙l)’ in the following).

We train a convolutional neural network (CNN) with a batch size of 20 using the following architecture: the first convolutional block consists of two 3×3333\times 3 convolution layers with 32 channels, ReLU activation, followed by a 2×2222\times 2 max pooling layer and 0.2 dropout; the second convolutional block contains two 3×3333\times 3 convolution layers with 64 channels, ReLU activation, followed by a 2×2222\times 2 max pooling layer and 0.3 dropout; a fully connected layer with 120 units and ReLU activation; and a final 10-unit softmax layer. The network takes an input of size 20×3×32×32203323220\times 3\times 32\times 32 and produces an output of size 20×10201020\times 10.

The learning rate is set to η=0.1𝜂0.1\eta=0.1. If not especially noted, the local period and edge period are set to τl=6subscript𝜏𝑙6\tau_{l}=6 and τe=10subscript𝜏𝑒10\tau_{e}=10, separately. The Mob-HierFAVG algorithm is run for up to K=600𝐾600K=600 cloud epochs.

V-B Performance

V-B1 Impact of initial data distribution

The performance of HFL under several initial data distributions is shown in Fig 5. For the i.i.d. case, the maximum test accuracies of the static and mobile scenarios are approximately equal, which is consistent with (29). For the local non-i.i.d. case, the static accuracy is the same as the mobile accuracy, which is different from the local non-i.i.d. / edge i.i.d. case in (30). This is because the number of simulated vehicles is not large enough to produce edge i.i.d., and as long as edge non-i.i.d. happens in any cloud epoch, the effect of data fusion emerges, which offsets the negative effect of model shuffling. For the edge non-i.i.d. case, mobility obviously increases the performance. Specifically, when l=2𝑙2l=2, mobility improves the accuracy by 5.7% (74.9% to 80.6%); when l=1𝑙1l=1, mobility improves the accuracy by 15.1% (40.9% to 56.0%). These results reflect that if an edge server holds fewer classes, the accuracy of HFL decreases, while the accuracy improvement brought by mobility increases.

Furthermore, by comparing the results of local non-i.i.d. and edge non-i.i.d. cases when l=2𝑙2l=2, we find that the local non-i.i.d. case achieves a higher accuracy than the edge non-i.i.d. case in the static scenario, but reaches a similar accuracy with mobility. This phenomenon may originate from the equivalent aggregation period of heterogeneous data. In the local non-i.i.d. case, the data heterogeneity exists at the local level, so the edge aggregation sees a fusion of heterogeneous data, and thus the equivalent aggregation period is τlsubscript𝜏𝑙\tau_{l} local updates. In the edge non-i.i.d. case, the data heterogeneity exists at the edge level, so only the cloud aggregation sees a fusion of heterogeneous data with the equivalent aggregation period of τl​τesubscript𝜏𝑙subscript𝜏𝑒\tau_{l}\tau_{e} local updates. As demonstrated in [48], a greater aggregation period results in worse training performance for heterogeneous data. However, when the vehicles start moving, data of different edge servers gradually mix up, and thus the equivalent aggregation period goes back to τlsubscript𝜏𝑙\tau_{l}.

V-B2 Impact of vehicle speed

For the edge non-i.i.d. case, the impact of vehicle speed v𝑣v on the convergence speed is further studied. As is shown in Fig. 6(a), the test accuracies of the scenarios with mobility, i.e., v>0𝑣0v>0, are obviously higher than the one achieved when v=0𝑣0v=0. Furthermore, the rounds to reach certain target accuracies are shown in Fig. 6(b), which demonstrates that with high accuracy requirements, mobility greatly reduces the training epochs, and thus saves resource utilization and power consumption. Also, Fig. 6(b) indicates that it takes nearly the same number of cloud epochs to reach the accuracy of 60% for all scenarios. Models of this accuracy contain basic features of the datasets without the information of class variety and generally can be achieved by pre-training. Actually, this situation usually happens in vehicular networks. For example, for the beam selection task, when the channel condition changes, the model needs to be fine-tuned, and the original model, which carries the basic features for beams, can be set as the pre-trained model.

Therefore, we further assume that the training is started from a pre-trained model with a test accuracy of 60%. With a pre-trained model, the training time is obviously decreased, as shown in Fig. 6(c) and 6(d). Besides, Fig. 6(d) illustrates that a higher speed generally results in faster convergence. In particular, it takes only 142 cloud epochs for the v=30𝑣30v=30 case to reach an accuracy of 75%, reduced by 65.5% compared with the v=0𝑣0v=0 case (412 epochs), and 39.8% compared with the v=1𝑣1v=1 case (236 epochs). These results are in line with the convergence analysis in Section IV.

On the other hand, the improvement brought by high mobility is limited. In our simulations, both the final accuracy and the convergence speed typically saturate beyond v=6𝑣6v=6 m/s𝑚𝑠m/s. Fig. 7 demonstrates that the evolving trends of 1-norm of the average probability difference of edges in v=6,15,30𝑣61530v=6,15,30 m/s𝑚𝑠m/s cases are similar. Therefore, the convergence performance saturates possibly because data from different edge servers is sufficiently mixed at v=6𝑣6v=6 m/s𝑚𝑠m/s, and no further gains can be achieved with even higher mobility. We also notice that the average probability difference does not monotonically decrease with time, but oscillates downward in a certain cycle. Besides, the theoretical analysis indicates that the average probability difference goes to zero after a long enough time, but during the simulation time, the value only decreases to around 0.4. These results may originate from the limited number of vehicles and training epochs.

V-B3 Impact of aggregation periods

Eq. (31) shows that the impact of mobility is correlated with not only the sojourn probability but also the aggregation periods and the number of vehicles. Further simulations are carried out for verification. Fig. 8(a) shows the test accuracy of the static and mobile scenarios for several values of τesubscript𝜏𝑒\tau_{e}. In the static scenario, a small τesubscript𝜏𝑒\tau_{e} results in faster convergence speed and higher accuracy; while in the mobile scenario, different values of τesubscript𝜏𝑒\tau_{e} report similar convergence speed and test accuracy values. This finding indicates that mobility reduces the reliance on cloud aggregation, and thus saves communication resources.

The impact of local period τlsubscript𝜏𝑙\tau_{l} is shown in Fig. 8(b). Although not explicitly expressed in the mobility factor, mobility slightly enhances the benefits of edge aggregation. For the τl=12subscript𝜏𝑙12\tau_{l}=12 case, mobility improves the max test accuracy by 5.2% (73.5% to 78.7%); while for the τl=3subscript𝜏𝑙3\tau_{l}=3 case, mobility improves the max test accuracy by 6.0% (76.4% to 82.4%).

From another perspective, if the local updates per cloud epoch τl​τesubscript𝜏𝑙subscript𝜏𝑒\tau_{l}\tau_{e} are fixed, we can learn the trade-off between the edge aggregation and cloud aggregation. Fig. 8(c) tells that mobility brings greater improvement when edge aggregation is more frequent.

V-B4 Impact of the number of vehicles

As demonstrated in Fig. 9(a), the number of edge servers does not influence the convergence in the static scenario, but if the vehicles have mobility, fewer edge servers contribute to higher test accuracy. However, this result is based on the assumption that the cloud server has a certain coverage. If the number of edge servers decreases, each edge server needs to cover a larger area, with a longer communication delay during the edge aggregation.

Fig. 9(b) demonstrates that more vehicles lead to higher test accuracy for both the static and mobile scenarios. This result basically matches the conclusion in FL: with more clients participating in the edge aggregation, the aggregated model is more stable, thus bringing a higher convergence speed. Besides, the improvement caused by adding vehicles is sharper for the mobile scenario, probably because with more vehicles, the probability difference of edges becomes smaller as the data of vehicles mix up.

VI conclusion

In this article, we have investigated the impact of mobility on data-heterogeneous HFL. The convergence analysis of HFL has been conducted, showing that mobility influences the performance of HFL by fusing the edge data and shuffling the edge models. Next, the mobility factors under three initial data distributions for classification tasks have been derived, which proves that mobility increases the convergence speed of HFL in the edge non-i.i.d. case. Furthermore, when the edge servers form a ring topology, a higher speed of vehicles lead to faster convergence of HFL. Simulations have been carried out on the CIFAR-10 dataset and the SUMO platform, demonstrating the benefits of mobility from multiple perspectives. Results have shown that mobility brings an increase in test accuracy by up to 15.1% in the edge non-i.i.d. case. Higher speed results in higher test accuracy, while the achieved accuracy saturates when the speed of vehicles exceeds 666 m/s. Moreover, mobility has also shown the potential for reducing training costs.

This is a simple extension of (106) if we consider a no-mobility training procedure where vehicles follow the topology of τ𝜏\tau-th iteration.

Taking (141) into (140) and summing up over τ0subscript𝜏0\tau_{0}, we obtain

(143)

Appendix D proof of Proposition 2

To prove the proposition, we first introduce a lemma.

Lemma 10.

[49]Suppose transition probability matrix 𝐐𝐐\boldsymbol{Q} satisfies ∥λ∗∥<1delimited-∥∥subscript𝜆1\lVert\lambda_{*}\rVert<1 and is diagonalizable. Then there is a unique stationary distribution π𝜋\pi on X𝑋X and, given an initial distribution μ0subscript𝜇0\mu_{0} and point x∈X𝑥𝑋x\in X, there is a constant lx>0subscript𝑙𝑥0l_{x}>0 such that

∥μk​(x)−π​(x)∥1≤lx​∥λ∗∥j.subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜇𝑘𝑥𝜋𝑥1subscript𝑙𝑥superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜆𝑗\lVert\mu_{k}\left(x\right)-\pi\left(x\right)\rVert_{1}\leq l_{x}\lVert\lambda_{*}\rVert^{j}. (147)

Based on the lemma, we further let 𝑸[j]=[𝒔1[j];𝒔2[j],…;𝒔C[j]]superscript𝑸delimited-[]𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒔1delimited-[]𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒔2delimited-[]𝑗…superscriptsubscript𝒔𝐶delimited-[]𝑗\boldsymbol{Q}^{[j]}=[\boldsymbol{s}_{1}^{[j]};\boldsymbol{s}_{2}^{[j]},...;\boldsymbol{s}_{C}^{[j]}], so the evolution of 𝑸[j]superscript𝑸delimited-[]𝑗\boldsymbol{Q}^{[j]} can be regarded as C𝐶C separate distributions that converge to steady distribution. Assume the global dataset is balanced, and thus we have ∥𝒔c[j]∥1=∥𝒔c′[j]∥1subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝒔𝑐delimited-[]𝑗1subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝒔superscript𝑐′delimited-[]𝑗1\lVert\boldsymbol{s}_{c}^{[j]}\rVert_{1}=\lVert\boldsymbol{s}_{c^{\prime}}^{[j]}\rVert_{1} for all c,c′𝑐superscript𝑐′c,c^{\prime}, and we can calculate them by

∑c=1C∥𝒔c[j]∥1=∑n=1N∥𝒒n[j]∥1=N,superscriptsubscript𝑐1𝐶subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝒔𝑐delimited-[]𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝒒𝑛delimited-[]𝑗1𝑁\sum\limits_{c=1}^{C}\lVert\boldsymbol{s}_{c}^{[j]}\rVert_{1}=\sum\limits_{n=1}^{N}\lVert\boldsymbol{q}_{n}^{[j]}\rVert_{1}=N, (148)

so ∥𝒔c[j]∥1=NCsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝒔𝑐delimited-[]𝑗1𝑁𝐶\lVert\boldsymbol{s}_{c}^{[j]}\rVert_{1}=\frac{N}{C} for all c𝑐c. Then we define 𝒔~c[j]=CN​𝒔c[j]superscriptsubscriptbold-~𝒔𝑐delimited-[]𝑗𝐶𝑁superscriptsubscript𝒔𝑐delimited-[]𝑗\boldsymbol{\tilde{s}}_{c}^{[j]}=\frac{C}{N}\boldsymbol{s}_{c}^{[j]} to make it regularized distribution.

Taking the distribution above into (147), we get

∥𝒔~c[j]​(n)−1N∥1≤ln,c​∥λ∗∥j,subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscriptbold-~𝒔𝑐delimited-[]𝑗𝑛1𝑁1subscript𝑙𝑛𝑐superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜆𝑗\lVert\boldsymbol{\tilde{s}}_{c}^{[j]}\left(n\right)-\frac{1}{N}\rVert_{1}\leq l_{n,c}\lVert\lambda_{*}\rVert^{j}, (149)

which holds for all n𝑛n.

So we can calculate the probability divergence by

∥𝒒−𝒒n[j]∥1subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒒subscriptsuperscript𝒒delimited-[]𝑗𝑛1\displaystyle\lVert\boldsymbol{q}-\boldsymbol{q}^{[j]}_{n}\rVert_{1} =∑c=1C∥𝒔c[j]​(n)−1C∥1=∑c=1C∥NC​𝒔~c[j]​(n)−1C∥1absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑐1𝐶subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝒔𝑐delimited-[]𝑗𝑛1𝐶1superscriptsubscript𝑐1𝐶subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑁𝐶superscriptsubscriptbold-~𝒔𝑐delimited-[]𝑗𝑛1𝐶1\displaystyle=\sum\limits_{c=1}^{C}\lVert\boldsymbol{s}_{c}^{[j]}\left(n\right)-\frac{1}{C}\rVert_{1}=\sum\limits_{c=1}^{C}\lVert\frac{N}{C}\boldsymbol{\tilde{s}}_{c}^{[j]}\left(n\right)-\frac{1}{C}\rVert_{1} (150)
=NC​∑i=1C∥𝒔~c[j]​(n)−1N∥1≤N​Ln​∥λ∗∥j,absent𝑁𝐶superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐶subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscriptbold-~𝒔𝑐delimited-[]𝑗𝑛1𝑁1𝑁subscript𝐿𝑛superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜆𝑗\displaystyle=\frac{N}{C}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{C}\lVert\boldsymbol{\tilde{s}}_{c}^{[j]}\left(n\right)-\frac{1}{N}\rVert_{1}\leq NL_{n}\lVert\lambda_{*}\rVert^{j}, (151)

where Ln=∑c=1Cln,csubscript𝐿𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑐1𝐶subscript𝑙𝑛𝑐L_{n}=\sum\limits_{c=1}^{C}l_{n,c}.
